title: Does reading Chinese poems improve my Chinese? - Quora

response.answer_text: The short answer; No, reading Chinese poems will do little to improve your Chinese. (I recently wrote a blog post about this Will Reading Chinese Poems Improve my Chinese? ) The truth of the matter is that Chinese poetry can be very beautiful. Diligent students of hanzi know that many Chinese characters are full of meaning and nuance. When written as prose, the characters combined with words and context weave a story of deeper meaning, insight, and reflection. I must confess there have been occasions after reading, pondering, and ultimately comprehending a poem, it was as if I had uncovered a hidden treasure that brought not only peaceful satisfaction but seemed to convey wisdom of the ages. With that in mind, it may be no wonder that some instructors with advanced Chinese levels may extol the virtues of Chinese poetry and even require their students to become diligent pupils of the classics. While the rewards can be sweet, reading Chinese poetry is not an optimal way to improve your Chinese. For a very SIMPLE (and I emphasize simple) example, consider the following poem that is included in the first semester Chinese text books for 1st graders in Shanghai.  《画》 远看山有色， 近听水无声。 春去花还在， 人来鸟不惊。    If you could read this, congratulations! It’s a nice poem isn’t it? It causes you to stop for a moment and reflect on the beauty and tranquility of the scene with beautiful, colorful mountains, quiet streams, spring flowers still in bloom, and birds unfrightened by the approach of people. Amazingly, it is also one of the most simple poems in existence. Of the 20 characters in the poem, 18 are found within HSK level 3 while the other 2 are at HSK level 4 (无 and 惊). Despite the simplicity of this poem, here is why it it’s not very helpful to learning Chinese. It’s too short. By nature poems are short and are intended to be slowly chewed and digested. Poems are not designed to be long, however reading longer texts greatly aide in language acquisition because there is greater repetition, leading to the next reason….No repetition. Research suggests that it requires 10-20 encounters with a word before they are truly learned and much more to learn how it is used with different word pairs and in different contexts. Poems cannot offer this type of repetition.It does not reflect how people talk or communicate in daily life. Do we speak English the same way poems are written in English? Not unless your name is Longfellow. The same goes for Chinese. It’s rich and beautiful, but people do not speak like this in everyday life.Low context. Usually there is little context given within the poem or the context is vague. As result, it becomes unclear if or how the words/characters/phrases are used in everyday life.Frequent use of obscure characters. This is more common when reading classical poetry. Characters arise that refer to very specific parts of a soldiers weapon or perhaps you’ll learn the very specific character for duckweed: “萍” (both true stories). The only time you will run across some of these characters is when you are reading “Romance of the Three Kingdoms” or… classical poetry. You frequently will spend more time with a dictionary and translating in order to comprehend the passage. In the end you may understand what you read, but you’ll likely forget the characters you were exposed to.Being able to read Chinese poetry is wonderful! However instead of looking at Chinese poetry as a step to better Chinese, it would be better viewed as a reward for hard work.

Yes. Particularly the short story Lion eating in the den by Zhao Yuanren <施氏食獅史> “石室詩士施氏，嗜獅，誓食十獅。施氏時時適市視獅。十時，適十獅適市。是時，適施氏適市。氏視是十獅，恃矢勢，使是十獅逝世。氏拾是十獅屍，適石室。石室濕，氏使侍拭石室。石室拭，氏始試食是十獅。食時，始識是十獅，實十石獅屍。試釋是事。” The translation is thus; The story of Mr.Shi eating lions> “There was a poet named Mr.Shi who lives in a stone den. He liked to eat lions, and vowed to eat ten lions. Therefore Mr. Shi would usually visit the market to look for lions. At 10 o’clock exactly ten lions just arrived at the market. At that very moment, Mr.Shi shot a few arrows from his bow and killed those ten lions. Mr. Shi then brought the ten dead lions back to his stone den. Because the den might be too wet to store the lions. So he ordered his servant to clean and dry the den. After the den was cleaned, Mr.Shi started to try to eat those ten lions. However, only until he was eating the lions he found out that those ten dead lions were actually ten stone lions. Would you try to explain what was happening?” But don't read it out loud in mandarin, you'll sound like a nutter. Written in Pinyin romanization for reading: <Shī Shì Shí Shī Shǐ> “Shí Shì Shī Shì Shī Shì, Shì Shī, Shì Shí Shí Shī.Shì Shí Shí Shì Shì Shì Shī. Shí Shí, Shì Shí Shī Shì Shì. Shì Shí, Shì Shī Shì Shì Shì. Shì Shì Shì Shí Shī, Shì Shǐ Shì, Shǐ Shì Shí Shī Shì Shì. Shì Shí Shì Shí Shī Shī, Shì Shí Shì. Shí Shì Shī, Shì Shǐ Shì Shì Shí Shì. Shí Shì Shì, Shì Shǐ Shì Shí Shì Shí Shī. Shí Shí, Shǐ Shí Shì Shí Shī, Shí Shí Shí Shī Shī. Shì Shì Shì Shì.” Enjoy.

Yes of course it will! Poetry is a vital expression of any major language, and it’s always worth exploring as an approach to the culture it represents, while also indicating the characteristics of a language. ‘Shall I compare thee to a summer's day? . . .’ (Shakespeare)‘Kennst du das Land wo die Zitronen blühen . . .’ (Goethe)‘Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita . . . ’ (Dante) etc etc An intermediate level student should be able to handle a little poetry, even if it's only two or three verses. Sensible study of a few significant poems will always be beneficial. This is true of Chinese as well as most other languages.  Chinese poetry has arguably the longish continuous development and technical complexity of any Asian art form — making it almost comparable to, say, western music. That in itself makes it interesting, in showing off what the Chinese language is capable of accomplishing, however I think the main practical benefit of reading poetry, especially for a non-tonal native speaker, is to try to get to grips with the problems of the sound of Chinese.  Chinese poetry not only has rhyme, but in the case of ‘regulated verse' it also has internal tone patterns. Listening to a native speaker read Chinese poetry and then  attempting to imitate the cadences for many students of Chinese will bring them closer to the essential sound of the language. (While the phonology of the verse has obviously changed since the Tang, or whenever, sufficient remains for the poetry to still ‘work’ in modern Chinese.) The 5-syllable jueju, for example by Li Bai and Wang Wei, are minimal in length and easy enough for everybody to appreciate.

Not so sure about the modern poems, but if you meant ancient poems, IMHO the answer is yes, but in the long run. It could be beneficial from the following aspects: Poems help you understand the mindset of Chinese culture. Since our culture is rather continuous, a lot of philosophy, or value, is still valid, cherished and advocated in modern days. Most ancient poems have a clear but delicately put implications, e.g. patriotic, nostalgic, romantic feelings and ambition of serving the country or self-accomplishment, etc. Some feelings are shared across cultures.From the aesthetic point of view, reading, or rather appreciating, poems could lure you more to Chinese, which is so beautifully written in those poems. When I read poems by W.B. Yeats, it was like a complete strange person across the globe, across time, conveyed his idea in those beautiful words, and yet can be share with and appreciated by you.As for the everyday Chinese conversation, ancient poems may not be really helpful directly since modern Chinese is different, but with a quotation from ancient poems, you could be considered as a more native Chinese speaker. We like quoting ancient things, even in daily lives.

In all honesty (I'm half Chinese/half American) Unless you are highly proficient in Chinese already (therefore not in dire need of improvement) it's not an economic use of your time.  Studying and then conversing with people in Chinese and trying to use new words without worrying about being corrected is a much better use of time until at least you are in the 6 or 7 range on the HSK test.  That being said, reading Chinese poetry might generally make you a deeper person, perhaps even calmer. You will also gain an interesting perspective into concepts like metaphor, rhythm, rhyme, etc.  through a very different cultural lens.

I think so. Chinese poems contain lots of Chinese culture and history. It will make your Chinese knowledge background stronger and you will have lots of potential to improve your Chinese language. In Chinese poetry, you will find the true beauty of the Chinese language. If you can really learn and understand it, I believe your Chinese phonetic & phonology system, grammar and characters will improve incredibly. Your level will be far beyond the normal learners. Of course the further you want to go, the tougher the challenges you will go through. It`s a quite hard process. Even many Chinese people can hardly understand those poems. Poem is like the peak of the mountain, you can`t skip the foundation and  arrive there.

Actually,there are a lot of differences between modern Chinese and ancient Chinese .Sometimes  it's  difficult to understand them  thoroughly  even for a native Chinese. And although ancient  poems are really beautiful and wonderful , they  are rarely used in everyday life. Just as no one would study English by reading Shakespeare in China ,reading Chinese poems is really not a good idea for a beginner.     Why not choose other ways to improve Chinese skill ? such as chatting with native Chinese ,reading Chinese news etc..     But if you are good at Chinese now, just go ahead ! I believe you will fall in love with them once you understand them!-----   btw, I want to improve my English but keeping  thousands of  English words in mind  is  too hard for me . Chinese poems especially the ancient poems are difficult for Chinese, not to mention non-Chinese speaker. I think it depends on what aim you want to achieve, if you want to improve your oral Chinese, you can speak over and over again, you'd better find a Chinese people to practice. But if you can't find the Chinese people, you can choose a better way of learning Chinese by listening to hymns and recitals, or watching movies which can inspire your interest, so I recommend a hymn and a recital for you.

I think it depends on what Chinese poems you read. Chinese poems are generally divided into two kinds: metrical and free style. Metrical poems are traditional and far away from spoken Chinese. So they are not very useful to improve your spoken Chinese. Anyway, (traditional) educated Chinese consider the ability to write metrical poems makes a person 'gentleman'. As for free style poems, they are to some extent spoken Chinese, and can be used to improve both your spoken and written Chinese. However, just don't just rely on reading poems to improve your language skills, there are more efficient ways, I think.

Yes, it can help, because rhythm and rhyme can help you memorize words faster. Also, memorizing and reciting Chinese poems can help improve your Chinese pronunciation. There are several different vowel combinations in Chinese, and each has its own distinct sound. If you are already in the advance level, then Yes.  Go ahead. Appreciate the beauty in its obscurity and its inner historical value.  But I think that the advance learner wouldn't bother to ask this question in the first place. So the answer is NO. Poem is not the good way to improve your main basic & intermediate language skill.  It is preferable to choose to go with the article that you have shared social context and personal interest as much as possible while provide enough reasonable linguistic challenge to your current level.

In China, children have some ancient and modern Chinese poems in their textbook of mother language. When you were learning your mother tongue as a kid, hadn't you have learnt some interesting and easy poems? Everything can be divided from simple to complicated, so can Chinese poems. Simple ones are suitable for language learning beginners. Here is a simple poem for Chinese kids in their textbook: Snowflake One piece two pieces three four pieces, Five pieces six pieces seven eight pieces. Nine pieces ten pieces ten and one pieces, All pieces fall into water and disappear. 雪花 一片两片三四片， 五片六片七八片。 九片十片十一片， 飞入水中都不见。 What do you think of this poem as a way to learn Chinese numbers? As simple poems can be helpful for language beginners, complicated poems maybe need advanced language learners. And the key is to find suitable Chinese poems for your learning, according to your present language level.

Yes, it will. Of course people don't speak in everyday 21st-century life the way Li Bai or Bo Juyi wrote in poems, but many lines from Classical Chinese poems are part of everyday discourse. Even in modern Chinese culture, allusions to famous poems are much more common than in, say, modern English-speaking culture.  So even if your interest in the Chinese language is purely mercenary, purely business-oriented, it'll still help you. If your interest is broader and more humane, then of course it'll help even more.

No, it won't help your modern Chinese one bit. It won't even be as helpful as studying Classical Chinese prose. But if you want to study it out of interest, go ahead! It's always fun learning about something that you're interested in.
